revision.text:
{{Infobox company |name = Diamond Comic Distributors, Inc. |logo = Diamond Comic Distributors.png |type = [[Private company|Private]] |foundation = {{Start date and age|1982}} |location_city = [[Hunt Valley, Maryland|Hunt Valley]], Maryland |location_country = United States |key_people = {{Plainlist| * [[Stephen A. Geppi]], CEO * Chuck Parker, {{small|Exec VP and COO}} * Larry Swanson, {{small|VP Finance and CFO}} * Roger Fletcher, {{small|VP Sales and Marketing}} * John Wurzer, {{small|VP Operations}} * Tim Lenaghan, {{small|VP Purchasing}} * Chris Powell, {{small|VP Retailer Services}} * Mike Schimmel, {{small|Sales Director}} * Dan Manser, {{small|Marketing Director}} }} |industry = [[Comics]] |products = comic book distribution |revenue = $500 million |num_employees = 540 |homepage = {{URL|http://www.diamondcomics.com}} |footnotes = }} '''Diamond Comic Distributors, Inc.''' (often called '''Diamond Comics''', '''DCD''', or casually '''Diamond''') is a [[comic book]] [[distribution (business)|distributor]] serving retailers in North America and worldwide. They transport comic books and graphic novels from both big and small comic book publishers, or suppliers, to [[retail]]ers, as well as other pop-culture products such as toys, games, and apparel. Diamond distributes to the [[direct market]] in the United States, and has an exclusive distribution arrangements with most major U.S. comic book publishers, including [[Dark Horse Comics]], [[DC Comics]], [[IDW Publishing]],<ref>[http://www.comicsbeat.com/2010/03/18/idw-become-premier-publisher-with-diamond/ "IDW Becomes Diamond Premiere Publisher"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100322225332/http://www.comicsbeat.com/2010/03/18/idw-become-premier-publisher-with-diamond/ |date=2010-03-22 }}</ref> [[Image Comics]], [[Marvel Comics]], and more.
Diamond is also the parent company of [[Alliance Game Distributors]], Diamond Book Distributors, Diamond UK, [[Diamond Select Toys]], [[Gemstone Publishing]], E. Gerber Products, Diamond International Galleries, Hake's Americana & Collectibles, Morphy's Auctions, the [[Geppi's Entertainment Museum]], and [[Baltimore (magazine)|''Baltimore'' magazine]],
Diamond is the publisher of ''Previews'', a monthly catalog/magazine showcasing upcoming comic books, graphic novels, toys, and other pop-culture merchandise available at comic book specialty shops. The publication is available to both comic shop retailers and consumers.
==History== In 1982, Baltimore-based comics retailer Steve Geppi founded Diamond Comic Distributors. Diamond became the successor to direct market pioneer [[Phil Seuling]]'s distribution dream when it took over [[New Media/Irjax]]'s warehouses in 1982. Diamond further bought out early-distributor [[Bud Plant Inc.]] in 1988, and main rival [[Capital City Distribution]] in 1996, to assume a near-monopoly on comics distribution, including exclusivity deals with the major [[List of comics publishing companies|comic book publishers]].
=== Beginnings === By 1981/82 Geppi had four comics retail locations and was already "doing a little informal distributing... for smaller retailers."<ref name="Success">Warshaw, Michael with illustration by [[Neal Adams]], "From Mailman to Tycoon," ''[[Success (magazine)|Success]]'' (June, 1994), pp. 28–32</ref> Geppi found himself "one of the biggest accounts" for New Media/Irjax,<ref name="Success"/> and when the distributor "relocated to Florida, he asked Geppi to service more accounts for a bigger discount."<ref name="Success"/> One of the "last loyal customers" when New Media began having fiscal difficulties, Geppi made a deal: "[t]he owner was going into retail," so Geppi agreed to provide New Media/Irjax with "free books for a period of time in return for his account list," buying parts of the company, and founding Diamond Comic Distribution.<ref name="Success"/>
Geppi had been a sub-distributor for Hal Shuster's Irjax in the late 1970s.<ref name="DuinDD">Duin, Steve and [[Mike Richardson (publisher)|Richardson, Mike]] (ed.s) "[[Direct market|Direct Distribution]]" in ''Comics Between the Panels'' ([[Dark Horse Comics|Dark Horse Publishing]], 1998) {{ISBN|1-56971-344-8}}, p. 126-130</ref> In what [[Mile High Comics]]' [[Chuck Rozanski]] describes as an "incredibly risky and gutsy move," Geppi took over New Media/Irjax's "office and warehouse space" and, recalled Rozanski, had to "sort out the good customers from the bad overnight" negotiating with creditors to continue Shuster's distribution business as Diamond Comic Distribution.<ref name="DuinDiamond"/> Almost overnight, noted Rozanski, "[h]e went from being a retailer in Baltimore to having warehouses all over the place."<ref name="DuinDiamond"/>
Geppi named his new company 'Diamond' "after the imprint [[Marvel Comics]] used on non-returnable comics," and although the "publisher discontinued the symbol" months later, the name remained.<ref name="Success"/> "Diamond grew an average of 40 percent a year," as comics retail took off.<ref name="Success"/>
In 1983, Diamond hired an accounting firm, and in 1985 hired "no-nonsense CPA" Chuck Parker "as Diamond's first controller".<ref name="Success"/> In 1994, Diamond employee Mark Herr noted that this move was Geppi's "best decision", as Parker "cares nothing about the comics. To him, it's dollars and cents."<ref name="Success"/> Parker describes his role as "smooth[ing] the emotion out of some decisions. Steve [Geppi] is a visionary and a risk-taker... and I tend to be more conservative."<ref name="Success"/>
===Expansion=== After starting his business through buying New Media/Irjax's warehouses and offices in 1982, Geppi's distribution company has bought out many other distribution companies since. Many fans "with little experience" started rival distribution companies only to "find they were in over their heads," allowing Geppi to "[buy] out the smart ones or pick... up the pieces after the stupid ones went out of business," according to Herr.<ref name="Success"/> Diamond was aided in his efforts by the publishers themselves. In the early 1980s, Marvel and DC Comics provided trade terms favorable for larger distributors and those with efficient freight systems, effectively "play[ing] into the hands of the major distributors such as Capital and Diamond," and hastening the demise of smaller distributors.<ref name="DuinDD"/>
==== Bud Plant Inc. ==== Most notably, in 1988, Geppi bought up early mail-order distributor Bud Plant Inc.,<ref>"Bud Plant Sells Out to Diamond," ''The Comics Journal'' #124 (August 1988), pp. 9-10.</ref> who had himself bought out [[Charles Abar Distribution]] in 1982.<ref name="DuinPlant">Duin, Steve and [[Mike Richardson (publisher)|Richardson, Mike]] (ed.s) "Bud Plant" in ''Comics Between the Panels'' ([[Dark Horse Comics|Dark Horse Publishing]], 1998) {{ISBN|1-56971-344-8}}, p. 356-357</ref> Plant had, since 1970, been selling [[underground comics]] (a field which Geppi and fellow distributor [[Buddy Saunders]] had tended to steer clear of).<ref name="DuinPlant"/> After making $19m in sales in 1987, Diamond bought West Coast distributor Plant's business<ref>Plant maintains a mail-order and Internet presence in art books, trade paperbacks and rare books, however. Duin, Steve and [[Mike Richardson (publisher)|Richardson, Mike]] (ed.s) "Bud Plant" in ''Comics Between the Panels'' ([[Dark Horse Comics|Dark Horse Publishing]], 1998) {{ISBN|1-56971-344-8}}, p. 356-357</ref> in 1988 "and went national"<ref name="Success"/> thereby assuming control of "40 percent of the [[direct market|direct-sales market]]."<ref name="DuinPlant"/> (Diamond and Capital City Distribution had control of at least 70% between them.)
==== Further expansion ==== In 1990, Diamond acquired the Seattle-based sub-distributor [[Destiny Distribution]].<ref name=Diamond-timeline>[http://www.diamondcomics.com/Home/1/1/3/597?articleID=117735 "Diamond Timeline Chronicles 30 Years of Service & Success,"] Diamond Comic Distributors, Inc. official website. Accessed Feb. 10, 2015.</ref><ref>"Newswatch: Independent Meets Its Destiny," ''The Comics Journal'' #139 (December 1990), pp. 12-13.</ref> Destiny had been started by Phil Pankow in the early 1980s, and was initially supplied by Bud Plant. Also in 1990, Diamond acquired Oregon-based [[Second Genesis Distribution]]<ref name=Diamond-timeline /> (whose operations folded in 1991).<ref>"Second Genesis Delaying Its Exodus," ''The Comics Journal'' #140 (February 1991), p. 13.</ref>
In 1991, Diamond moved into the [[UK]] market, acquiring [[Pacific Comics|Pacific Distribution, Ltd.]]<ref name=Diamond-timeline /> In 1992, Diamond acquired the British distributor [[Titan Distributors]], an arm of [[Titan Entertainment Group]].<ref>"NewsWatch: Diamond Acquires Titan Distributors," The Comics Journal #154 (Nov. 1992), p. 14.</ref>
In 1994, Diamond acquired Staten Island-based distributor [[Comics Unlimited]].<ref name=Diamond-timeline /> By this point, Diamond had "27 warehouses in the U.S., Canada, and the U.K., employ[ing] between 750 and 900 people;" operated its own trucking line; and controlled 45% of the market, making $222 million in sales.<ref name="Success"/>
==== Heroes World and Capital City ==== In 1995, Marvel Comics challenged Diamond and main rival Capital City by buying the third largest distributor — [[Heroes World Distribution]] — and distributing its titles in-house.<ref name="DuinCC">Duin, Steve and [[Mike Richardson (publisher)|Richardson, Mike]] (ed.s) "Capital City" in ''Comics Between the Panels'' ([[Dark Horse Comics|Dark Horse Publishing]], 1998) {{ISBN|1-56971-344-8}}, p. 69</ref> Diamond reacted by outbidding Capital City for exclusive deals with Marvel's main rivals [[DC Comics]], as well as [[Dark Horse Comics|Dark Horse]], [[Image Comics|Image]], and [[Archie Comics]].<ref>"Newswatch: Tip 11: Go Exclusive with Diamond" ''The Comics Journal'' #185 (March 1996), p. 27.</ref> Capital City's response saw it sign exclusive deals with [[Kitchen Sink Press]] and [[Viz Comics]], but a year later faced the choice between bankruptcy and selling out. Diamond bought Capital City in the summer of 1996, assuming near-control of the comics distribution system.<ref name="DuinCC"/><ref name="bNet">[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0EIN/is_1996_July_26/ai_18526328 "Diamond Comic Distributors acquires Capital City Distribution; Comic distribution industry stabilized by purchase," bNet: Business Wire (July 26, 1996).]</ref> The purchase price was not disclosed, but the acquisition brought an estimated $50 million in sales revenue to Diamond.<ref name="bNet" />
In early 1997, when Marvel's Heroes World endeavor failed, Diamond also forged an exclusive deal with the House of Ideas<ref>"Hello Again: Marvel Goes with Diamond," ''The Comics Journal'' #193 (February 1997), pp. 9-10.</ref> — giving the company its own section of comics catalog ''Previews'' (not least because the DC/Dark Horse/Image deal gave contractual prominence to those companies) — making "Geppi... the sole king of comics industry distribution in the summer of 1996."<ref name="DuinDiamond"/>
==== Antitrust litigation ==== In 1997, Diamond's position in the comics industry, as "the sole source of most new comics products to comics specialty shops," ultimately saw the company become the subject of "an investigation by the [[United States Department of Justice|U.S. Justice department]] for possible [[antitrust]] violations."<ref name="DuinDD"/> The Justice Department launched an antitrust investigation into the comics industry and the alleged [[monopoly]] of Diamond Comics. The investigation was closed in November 2000, with no further action deemed necessary<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.comicbookresources.com/comicbrief/archives.cgi?category=1&view=11-00#973711307 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060322213439/http://www.comicbookresources.com/comicbrief/archives.cgi?category=1&view=11-00 |archivedate=2006-03-22 |title=Comic Book Resources > The Comic Brief > DOJ concludes investigation of Diamond Comic Distributors |accessdate=2009-05-29 }}</ref><ref>Dean, Michael, "Will DC Buy Diamond?" for ''[[The Comics Journal]]'', April 5, 2002. Accessed March 6, 2009</ref> on the basis that, although Diamond enjoyed a monopoly in the North American comic book direct market distribution, they did not enjoy a monopoly on book distribution (books including non-comic books).
==== Books and games ==== In addition to having cornered the American comics distribution market, Diamond includes a number of subsidiary and affiliated companies. UK and European comics distribution is served by Diamond UK, based in Runcorn, England.<ref name="Affil"/>
On August 31, 2000, Diamond Comic Distributors acquired [[Alliance Game Distributors]], North America's largest distributor of tabletop games.<ref name="baltimoresun-adams">{{cite web |url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2000-09-01/business/0009010129_1_geppi-comic-books-diamond-comic |title=Geppi, the comics king, is buying Alliance Games |date=September 1, 2000 |first=Paul |last=Adams |work=[[The Baltimore Sun]]}}</ref>
In 2002, Diamond consolidated its book trade into Diamond Book Distributors, marketing [[graphic novel]]s and [[Trade paperback (comics)|trade paperback]]s to bookstores including [[Barnes & Noble]], [[Ingram Content Group|Ingram]], [[Baker & Taylor]], [[Amazon.com]] and [[Borders Group|Borders]].<ref name="Affil"/>
==Criticism== In 1983, Diamond was criticized for taking exception to certain "adult"-themed titles and scenes, effectively causing the cancellation of a series called ''[[Void Indigo]]'' for its excessive violence.{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}}
In 1987, Geppi responded to "a graphic childbirth scene in ''[[Miracleman]]'' #9 [written by [[Alan Moore]]]." Geppi wrote to retailers that: {{cquote|"Diamond values its retailers too much to take chances on such a dangerous situation... We are not [[Censorship|censor]]s. We no more want someone deciding for us than you do. We cannot, however, stand by and watch the marketplace become a dumping ground for every sort of graphic fantasy that someone wants to live out. We have an industry to protect; we have leases to abide by; we have a community image to maintain."<ref name="DuinDiamond"/>}} This call for retailers to refuse to stock ''Miracleman''<ref>"Geppi of Diamond Calls on Retailers to Voice Objections to Publishers," ''The Comics Journal'' #113 (December 1986), pp. 12-14.</ref> led to accusations of censorship,<ref>"Diamond Policies Questioned," ''The Comics Journal'' #116 (July 1987), pp. 18-20.</ref> charges the company was forced to address when it criticized or refused to carry other titles, including books by Kitchen Sink Press,<ref name="TCJ Diamond Back Down" /> and [[Dave Sim]] in 1988,<ref name="TCJ Diamond Back Down">"Diamond Backs Down," ''The Comics Journal'' #121 (April 1988), 7.</ref><ref>"Diamond Distributors Clashes With Aardvark-Vanaheim," ''The Comics Journal'' #122 (March 1988), p. 7.</ref><ref>"A-V, Diamond Clash Again," ''The Comics Journal'' #122 (June 1988), pp. 20-21.</ref><ref>"Diamond Loosens Up," ''The Comics Journal'' #122 (June 1988), pp. 20.</ref> [[Jon Lewis (comics)|Jon Lewis]] in 1994,<ref>"Newswatch: Diamond Refuses to Distribute Xeric Winner ''True Swamp''," ''The Comics Journal'' #166 (February 1994), p. 39.</ref> and [[Mike Diana]] in 1996.<ref name="TCJ Bias">"What's the Story Behind Diamond's Rejection of Mike Diana?: Three Diana Comics Rejected in 1996: Publishers and Distributor give Different Reasons; Accusation of Bias against Small Publishers" ''The Comics Journal'' #192 (December 1996), pp. 7-10.</ref>
Diamond lost customers with this approach, however, "and eventually backed down."<ref name="Success"/> Geppi recalls compromising, and accepting "that as a distributor, I owed the retailers the product they wanted."<ref name="Success"/> In fact, in an attempt to prove Diamond did not practice censorship, the company joined DC Comics in 1993 to raise money for the industry's [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] advocacy group [[Comic Book Legal Defense Fund]].<ref>"Diamond and DC Raise Money for CBLDF," ''The Comics Journal'' #160 (June 1993), p. 18.</ref>
Because of its industry dominance, Diamond also faced charges it bullied publishers<ref>Stump, Greg. "News Watch: Paranoia? Some Retailers Fear Diamond," ''The Comics Journal'' #199 (October 1997), p. 12.</ref> and discriminated against small publishers. These charges first surfaced in 1988 when Diamond rejected [[Matt Feazell]]'s comic ''[[Ant Boy]]'',<ref>"Diamond Rejects Ant Boy" ''The Comics Journal'' #124 (August 1988), pp. 15-16.</ref><ref>Baisden, Greg. "Diamond Accepts ''Ant Boy''" ''The Comics Journal'' #125 (October 1988), pp. 17-18.</ref> and in 1989 when it similarly decided not to carry [[Allen Freeman]]'s ''Slam Bang'' anthology.<ref>"Diamond Distributors Rejects ''Slam Bang''" ''The Comics Journal'' #132 (November 1989), pp. 14-15.</ref>
After the industry consolidation of 1996, Diamond faced similar charges in 1996,<ref name="TCJ Bias" /> 1999,<ref>Spurgeon, Tom with Craig McKenney. "Diamond and the Small Press, Part II: Breaking the Cycle: Rick Veitch Leaves Diamond Behind," ''The Comics Journal'' #21 (November 1999), pp. 16-19.</ref> and 2000 (when smaller publishers like [[Fantagraphics]] and [[Drawn and Quarterly]] lodged complaints).<ref>Stroup, Tim and Mark Thompson. "Comic Distribution Headaches," ''Gauntlet: Exploring the Limits of Free Expression'' #19 (2000), pp. 19-23.</ref><ref>Spurgeon, Tom. "Is Diamond Necessary? Small Arts Comics Publishers and their Relationship with Diamond Comic Distributors," ''The Comics Journal'' #222 (April 2000), pp. 20-26.</ref><ref>Spurgeon, Tom. "The View from the Bottom: Do Small Arts Publishers See Diamond as a Help or a Hindrance?," ''The Comics Journal'' #225 (July 2000), pp. 12-17.</ref><ref>Spurgeon, Tom. "Dealing with Diamond: the Big-Little Publishers and the Big-Big Distributor," ''The Comics Journal'' #228 (November 2000), pp. 11-16.</ref>
== Publishing == Diamond's monthly comics retail catalog, ''Previews'' has been produced by Diamond for over twenty-five years for store owners and comic shop customers to order their products. It is additionally available for sale to customers to facilitate pre-orders from "pull and hold" or subscription customers who frequent comic shops on a regular basis. Comics publishers vie for space within the publication's pages, with Dark Horse, DC Comics, Image Comics, and [[IDW Publishing]] taking precedence as "Premier" publishers. Marvel Comics has its own mini-catalog of ''Marvel Previews'' available separately, for contractual reasons.
Geppi is also owner of [[Gemstone Publishing|Gemstone Publishing Inc.]], through which he publishes ''[[The Overstreet Comic Book Price Guide]]''.<ref name="GEM"/> Gemstone has also published [[Russ Cochran (publisher)|Russ Cochran]]'s [[EC Comics]] reprints, [[Disney comics]] and [[Blue Book]] price guide in the past as well.
=== ''Baltimore'' === In 1994, Geppi purchased ''[[Baltimore (magazine)|Baltimore]]'' magazine,<ref>"Newswatch: Geppi Buys ''Baltimore''," ''The Comics Journal'' #174 (February 1995), p. 29.</ref> "a 50,000 circulation monthly and one of the nation's oldest regional publications."<ref name="GEM">[http://www.geppismuseum.com/default.asp?t=1&m=1&c=52&s=508&ai=69010 Geppi's Entertainment Museum Press Room: "Geppi's Entertainment Museum President/CEO Stephen A. Geppi Bio"]. Accessed March 5, 2009</ref>
===Gemstone Publishing=== {{main|Gemstone Publishing}}
Geppi's publishing ventures in the comics field saw him create Gemstone Publishing Inc., which was formed in large part from other purchases. In 1992, Diamond bought [[Ernst Gerber|Ernst Gerber Publishing]] (publisher-author of the ''Photo-Journal Guide to Comics'').<ref name="DuinDiamond">Duin, Steve and [[Mike Richardson (publisher)|Richardson, Mike]] (ed.s) "Diamond Comic Distributors" in ''Comics Between the Panels'' ([[Dark Horse Comics|Dark Horse Publishing]], 1998) {{ISBN|1-56971-344-8}}, p. 125-126</ref> E. Gerber Products, LLC is a Diamond-affiliated company started by Gerber in 1977 which sells [[Mylar]] bags as well as "acid-free boxes and acid-free backing boards" for comics collectors to store their collection in.<ref name="Affil">[http://www.diamondcomics.com/public/default.asp?t=1&m=1&c=3&s=305&ai=36048 Diamond Comics Distributors, Inc. "Affiliated Companies"]. Accessed March 5, 2009</ref> In 1993, Geppi bought Russ Cochran Publishing.<ref name="DuinDiamond"/> Long-term EC Comics fan Cochran auctioned [[Bill Gaines]]' personal file copies of EC publications, as well as most pages of original EC artwork (which, almost uniquely, Gaines had maintained ownership and possession of), before being granted the reprint rights to the EC back catalog itself. Geppi included Cochran's publications — and Cochran himself — under his new imprint, Gemstone Publishing.<ref name="GEM"/>
In 1994, Geppi bought Overstreet Publishing, taking up the publishing reins of official-Blue Book price guide ''The Overstreet Comic Book Price Guide'', and other related publications, bringing them under the Gemstone imprint.<ref name="DuinDiamond"/> Geppi's publishing activities with Gemstone Publishing consist primarily of reprints of classic titles and artworks, as well as publications (including professional [[comics fanzine|fanzines]] "pro-zines") focusing heavily on the history of the comics medium. Many Gemstone publications revolve around ''[[Comic Book Marketplace]]''-editor and EC-shepherd Russ Cochran.
====EC Comics reprints==== {{main|EC Comics|EC Archives}}
Cochran, like Geppi, was a particular fan of [[Carl Barks]]' Disney comics, and had previously-published EC reprints in association with Disney-reprinter Gladstone Publishing. In the early 1990s, Geppi's Gemstone embarked on a full series of reprints of classic EC titles, starting with new reprints of the Cochran/Gladstone-reprints of ''[[The Haunt of Fear]]'', ''[[The Vault of Horror]]'' and ''[[Weird Science (comic)|Weird Science]]'' (all 1992). Gemstone also republished (in single issue and 'annual' — four issues per 'annual' — format) EC's ''[[List of EC Comics Publications#New Trend|New Trend]]'' and ''[[List of EC Comics Publications#New Direction|New Direction]]'' titles between 1992 and 2000.
In 2005, Gemstone added to Cochran's earlier-published oversize, hardback, black & white slip-cased "The Complete EC Library" collections with the complete ''[[List of EC Comics Publications#Picto-Fiction|Picto-Fiction]]'' collection, comprising the EC comics: ''[[Confessions Illustrated]]'', ''[[Crime Illustrated]]'', ''[[Shock Illustrated]]'' and ''[[Terror Illustrated]]'', along with "18 previously unseen stories, never published before".<ref>[http://www.bookpalace.com/acatalog/Home_Complete_EC_Library_31.html The Book Palace's "Complete EC Library" pages]. Accessed 12 March 2008.</ref>
In 2006, Gemstone began producing a more durable and luxurious series of hardback reprint collections; the [[EC Archives]] — similar to the [[DC Archive Editions|DC Archives]] and [[Marvel Masterworks]] volumes — which reprint in full-color hardback ('archival') format sequential compilations of the EC titles. Designed by art director/designer [[Michael Kronenberg]], a number of volumes have been released, with the entirety of the ''[[List of Entertaining Comics publications#New Trend|New Trend]]'' and ''[[List of Entertaining Comics publications#New Direction|New Direction]]'' planned for eventual release.<ref>[http://marvelmasterworksfansite.yuku.com/sreply/154876/t/WEIRD-SCIENCE-3-Error.html Michael Kronenberg posting at MarvelMasterworksFansite.Yuku.com, July 26, 2008]. Accessed September 1, 2008</ref> These EC Archives volumes have drawn praise for their quality, and feature introductions by such notable EC fans as [[George Lucas]], [[Steven Spielberg]], [[Joe Dante]] and [[Paul Levitz]].
====Disney comics==== {{main|Disney comics|Carl Barks}}
In December 2002, it was announced that "Gemstone Publishing had signed the license to publishing Disney comics in North America," with ex-Gladstone Publishing editor-in-chief John Clark joining Gemstone in the same position over its Disney line.<ref name="ScoopDisney">[http://scoop.diamondgalleries.com/public/default.asp?t=1&m=1&c=34&s=265&ai=42560&ssd=1/25/2003&arch=y "Starting Over — The Return of the Disney Comics" online in Diamond's ''Scoop'', January 25, 2003]. Accessed March 5, 2008</ref> Launched with a title for [[Free Comic Book Day]] 2003, the line started soon after with ''[[Walt Disney's Comics and Stories]]'' and ''[[Uncle Scrooge|Walt Disney's Uncle Scrooge]]'', both described by Clark as "monthly 64-page prestige-format books at $6.95, which is the same price they were when last produced, in 1998."<ref name="ScoopDisney"/> Other titles followed, and Gemstone held their license until early 2009.<ref>http://www.wolfstad.com/dcw/blog/2009/03/gemstone-ends-disney-license/</ref>
====Overstreet Comic Book Price Guide==== {{main|The Overstreet Comic Book Price Guide}}
The (Official) Overstreet Comic Book Price Guide, first published by Robert M. Overstreet in 1970 as one of the earliest authorities on [[United States|American]] [[comic book]] industry grading and collection values. Overstreet sold his company to Gemstone in 1994,<ref>"Newswatch: Overstreet Purchase Causes Stir," ''The Comics Journal'' #172 (November 1994), pp. 37-38.</ref> but continued to "serve as author and/or publisher of Geppi's Entertainment Publishing & Auctions' line of books."<ref>[http://www.geppisentertainment.com/bob_overstreet.html "Robert M. Overstreet" bio at ''Geppi's Entertainment'']. Accessed April 7, 2009 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090718002412/http://www.geppisentertainment.com/bob_overstreet.html |date=July 18, 2009 }}</ref> Publication of the ''Price Guide'' was taken over by Gemstone in 1998, Gemstone took over publication, and the twenty-eighth edition to the present have been (co-)published by Geppi's Gemstone publications.<ref>[http://www.comicsresearch.org/collect.html Comics Research.org's "Collecting Guides"]. Accessed March 7, 2009</ref> The ''Guide'''s 39th edition was published by Gemstone Publishing in 2009.
Overstreet also produced a variety of smaller publications updating his yearly guides on a monthly schedule. The most recent of these - ''Overstreet's Comic Price Review'' - began publication from Gemstone in July 2003, and was a monthly publication designed to update the yearly price guide more regularly, as well as provide articles, analysis and various lists of comics prices.
Gemstone published more than a hundred issues of the magazine ''Comic Book Marketplace'', a monthly magazine for comics fans focusing heavily on the [[Golden Age of Comic Books|Golden]] and [[Silver Age of Comic Books|Silver]] ages, while more popular magazines (such as ''[[Wizard (magazine)|Wizard]]'') skew more recent in focus.
====Future==== In early 2009, the future of Gemstone Publishing was unclear, after reports of unpaid printing bills, particularly from the EC Archives.<ref>[http://pwbeat.publishersweekly.com/blog/2009/02/18/steve-geppis-debt-woes-growing/ Heidi MacDonald, "Steve Geppi’s debt woes growing" in ''The Beat'', February 18, 2009]. Accessed March 5, 2009 {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120714211923/http://pwbeat.publishersweekly.com/blog/2009/02/18/steve-geppis-debt-woes-growing/ |date=July 14, 2012 }}</ref> In April, Geppi responded to the uncertainty, noting that while there had been "a reduction in staff at Gemstone," such moves did "not signal the end of Gemstone Publishing."<ref name="ScoopGemstone">[http://scoop.diamondgalleries.com/public/default.asp?t=1&m=1&c=34&s=259&ai=81682 "Rumors about Gemstone Publishing?"] in ''Scoop'', April 18, 2009</ref>
In 2008, Diamond introduced ComicSuite, an add-on application for Microsoft Dynamics’ Retail Management System (RMS) software. Together, ComicSuite & RMS give specialty storeowners a point-of-sale (POS) system specifically geared towards their unique business model, offering a host of exclusive features that grant you direct communication with Diamond databases, making it easier than ever before to place orders, track inventory and maintain “pull-and-hold” subscriptions for your customers."
== Affiliated and subsidiary companies == In 1995, Geppi founded Diamond International Galleries, which acquired Hake's [[Americana]] & [[Collectibles]] [[auction house]] (2004), and in 2005, Pennsylvania-based Morphy Auctions.<ref name="Antiq">[http://www.journalofantiques.com/Sept06%5Cfeature.html "Sneak Preview Geppi's Entertainment Museum at Camden Yards – Baltimore, Maryland," ''The Journal of Antiques and Collectibles'' (September 2006)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080705084736/http://www.journalofantiques.com/Sept06/feature.html |date=2008-07-05 }}. Accessed March 5, 2009</ref> In 1999, Geppi founded Diamond Select Toys, and in 2006 he founded [[Geppi's Entertainment Museum]] in Baltimore.
=== Alliance Game Distributors === [[Alliance Game Distributors]] is North America's largest distributor of tabletop games—[[role-playing game]]s, [[collectible card game]]s, [[miniature wargaming|miniature wargames]], [[board game]]s, and related merchandise—and the publisher of ''Game Trade Magazine''.<ref name="baltimoresun-adams" /> Alliance was acquired by Diamond in August 2000,<ref name="baltimoresun-adams" /> two years after being formed by the merger of game distributors [[Chessex]] and [[The Armory (game company)|The Armory]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sjgames.com/pyramid/sample.html?id=324 |title=Chessex and The Armory Form Alliance |work=[[Pyramid (magazine)|Pyramid]] |publisher=[[Steve Jackson Games]] |date=October 2, 1998}}</ref>
=== Diamond Select Toys & Collectibles === {{main|Diamond Select Toys}} Envisioned to create collectibles for children and adults, DST was founded in 1999 and has since licensed a variety of pop culture properties, including Marvel Comics, [[Transformers]], [[G.I. Joe: A Real American Hero]], [[Star Wars]], [[Star Trek]], [[Stargate]], [[Ghostbusters]], [[Halo (series)|Halo]], [[Buffy the Vampire Slayer]], [[Indiana Jones]], [[Battlestar Galactica]], [[24 (TV series)|24]] and [[Back to the Future]]. While they also make action figures in a variety of sizes, as well as banks, busts, statues and prop replicas, many of their licensed properties are released in the form of [[Minimates]], which has helped make Minimates one of the most prolific and diverse block figure toy lines in the world. In 2007, after years of partnership, Diamond Select Toys made a move to acquire select assets of New York-based design house Art Asylum,<ref>[http://www.toymania.com/news/messages/9319.shtml "Diamond Select Acquires Art Asylum"]</ref> the creators of Minimates and DST has since developed Minimates based on its own concepts, under the brands Minimates M.A.X. and Calico Jack's Pirate Raiders.
=== Diamond International Galleries === In 1995, Geppi "opened Diamond International Galleries," a showplace for comics and collectibles, part of Geppi's attempts to "see... collectibles attain serious respect."<ref name="Antiq"/> Nine years later, Diamond International Galleries purchased "one of the country’s first, and most respected, collectibles auction houses: Hake's Americana & Collectibles."<ref name="Antiq"/> In 2005, Geppi added the "[[Denver, Pennsylvania|Denver]], Pennsylvania-based Morphy Auctions" to his growing stable of parts of the collectibles market, which already included publishing the main comics price guide: ''The Overstreet Comic Book Price Guide''.<ref name="Antiq"/>
Geppi describes his International Galleries as being "at the heart of many significant opportunities to preserve, promote and present historical comic character collectibles," an endeavor that led to his establishing Geppi's Entertainment Museum.<ref name="Affil"/> Geppi's galleries showcase much of his private collection, including comics, [[film poster|movie poster]]s, toys, original artwork by individuals including "Carl Barks, [[Gustaf Tenggren|Gustav Tengren <small>(sic)</small>]], [[Alex Ross]], [[Murphy Anderson]], [[Joe Shuster]], [[Joe Simon]] and [[Charles Schulz]]."<ref name="Affil"/>
Diamond International Galleries has assisted "in such projects as DC's [[DC Archives|Archive series]]," as well as hosting industry events.<ref name="Affil"/>
=== Geppi's Entertainment Museum === {{main|Geppi's Entertainment Museum}}
Geppi's Entertainment Museum was a museum in [[Baltimore]], [[Maryland]], tracing the history of [[Popular culture|pop culture]] in American over the last four hundred years. Its collections include comic books, [[magazine]]s, [[film|movie]]s, [[newspaper]]s, [[television]], [[radio]] and [[video game]] [[Souvenir|memorabilia]], including comic books, movie posters, toys, buttons, badges, [[Breakfast cereal|cereal]] boxes, [[trading card]]s, dolls and figurines. The majority of the exhibits come from Geppi's private collection, while Geppi's daughter Melissa "Missy" Geppi-Bowersox became the executive vice-president of the museum in 2007, after Wendy Kelman left the museum on August 31, 2007, to start her own tourism consulting firm.<ref>{{cite web | last = Dash | first = Julehka | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Geppi's daughter takes reins of his new museum | work = | publisher = Baltimore Business Journal | date = 2007-09-14 | url = http://baltimore.bizjournals.com/baltimore/stories/2007/09/17/story5.html | doi = | accessdate = 2008-07-22}}</ref> The museum's curator is Dr. Arnold T. Blumberg, former editor at Geppi's Gemstone Publishing. The museum closed in June 2018. Geppi donated much of his collection to the [[Library of Congress]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Kaltenbach |first1=Chris |title=Geppi's Entertainment Museum to close as comic and art collection heads to Library of Congress |url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/entertainment/bs-fe-geppis-20180529-story.html |accessdate=27 July 2018 |work=The Baltimore Sun |date=30 May 2018}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of book distributors]]
==Notes== {{Reflist|33em}}
==References== * [http://www.answers.com/topic/diamond-comic-distributors-inc Hoover's profile of Diamond Comic Distributors]
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.diamondcomics.com}} * [http://www.comichron.com/monthlycomicssales.html The Comics Chronicles.com: Archive of Diamond comic book sales charts] * [http://sequart.org/magazine/27826/defending-diamond/ Sequart.org: "Defending Diamond"]—defense of the company, by Julian Darius (February 2006).

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.5.3)
revision.text:
{{Infobox court case | name = Entertainment Software Association v. Foti | court = [[Federal District Court]] | image = | date decided = | full name = Entertainment Software Association et al. v. Charles C. Foti, Jr. et al. | citations = | judges = [[James Brady (judge)|James J. Brady]] | prior actions = | subsequent actions = | opinions = }} '''''Entertainment Software Association v. Foti'''''<ref>{{cite web |url=https://cases.justia.com/federal/district-courts/louisiana/lamdce/3:2006cv00431/33659/1/0.pdf?ts=1208834325 |title=The complaint: Entertainment Software Association vs. Foti |website=Justia.com |access-date=October 13, 2016}}</ref> is a [[lawsuit]] filed on June 16, 2006 claiming that a [[Louisiana]] law should be declared unconstitutional. The recently passed Louisiana law was a way for the state to [[Video game controversy|censor video games]] by making it illegal to supply minors with video games considered violent, similar to laws making pornographic material unavailable to minors, but using violence as the criteria instead of sexual content. The lawsuit claims that the law infringed on the video game industry's constitutional right to freedom of expression.
The suit was successful in getting the law overturned in late 2006, and the plaintiffs were awarded attorney's fees in early 2007.
==Lawsuit == The [[plaintiff]]s in the case, the [[Entertainment Software Association]] (ESA) and the [[Entertainment Merchants Association]] (EMA), claimed that Louisiana criminal law RS 14:91.14 <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.legis.state.la.us/lss/lss.asp?doc=78708|title=Louisiana Statute: La RS 14:91.14 Prohibited sales of video or computer games to minors}}</ref> is unconstitutional on [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First]] and [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourteenth Amendment]] grounds. The defendants were [[Attorney General]] of Louisiana, [[Charles Foti|Charles C. Foti, Jr.]], and Doug Moreau, US [[District Attorney]] of the [[Parish]] of East [[Baton Rouge]]. Louisiana Governor [[Kathleen Blanco]] had signed [[Louisiana House Bill 1381|HB1381]] just the day before as Act 441 of the 2006 Louisiana Regular Session. The law made it illegal for someone in Louisiana to sell, lease or rent a violent video game (as defined in the Act) to someone under 18 years of age.
The suit pointed out that in other states, similar laws had already been declared unconstitutional, and thus impossible to enforce. Furthermore, according to the suit, the law would have chilling results with video games being less likely to be accessible by adults (as well as by minors, as was the initial intent of the law).
==Aftermath== Louisiana Middle District Judge James J. Brady issued a [[preliminary injunction]] on August 24, 2006.<ref name="GP injunction">{{cite web|url=http://gamepolitics.livejournal.com/347139.html |title=Judge Issues Preliminary Injunction Against Louisiana Law |accessdate=2007-01-20 |last=McCauley |first=Dennis |authorlink=Dennis McCauley |coauthors= |date=2006-08-25 |year= |month= |work= |publisher=[[GamePolitics.com]] |pages= |language= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070212163016/http://gamepolitics.livejournal.com/347139.html |archivedate=2007-02-12 |quote= |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
On July 17, 2006, Florida attorney and activist, [[Jack Thompson (attorney)|Jack Thompson]], who helped Louisiana Representative [[Roy Burrell]] author HB1381, filed an [[amicus curiae]] brief<ref>{{cite web |url=https://cases.justia.com/federal/district-courts/louisiana/lamdce/3:2006cv00431/33659/26/0.pdf?ts=1208833664 |title=John B. (Jack) Thompson's Motion for Leave to File ''Amicus Curiae'' Brief |website=Justia.com |access-date=October 13, 2016}}</ref> which Judge Brady denied <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamepolitics.com/images/legal/LA-JT-denied.pdf |title=Judge Brady DENIES Thompson's Motion for Leave to File ''Amicus Curiae'' Brief |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711072145/http://www.gamepolitics.com/images/legal/LA-JT-denied.pdf |archivedate=July 11, 2011 |access-date=October 13, 2016 |dead-url=yes}}</ref> on July 19, 2006.
The law was [[permanent injunction|permanently enjoined]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://cases.justia.com/federal/district-courts/louisiana/lamdce/3:2006cv00431/33659/52/0.pdf?ts=1208830269 |title=Court GRANTS permanent injunction prohibiting enforcement of La. R.S. 14:91.14 |website=Justia.com |access-date=October 13, 2016}}</ref> on November 29, 2006, and the court entered final judgment on December 5, 2006.
In his April 10, 2007 ruling,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gamepolitics.com/images/legal/LA-judge-on-fees.pdf |title=Judge Brady awards $92,000 to pay the plaintiffs' attorney's fees |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711071922/http://www.gamepolitics.com/images/legal/LA-judge-on-fees.pdf |archivedate=July 11, 2011 |access-date=October 13, 2016 |dead-url=yes}}</ref> Judge Brady stated that he was dumbfounded that the law even passed and was signed into law, given that similar laws were struck down in other states and those same states were forced to pay the legal fees of the plaintiffs. Judge Brady ordered the state to pay $92,000 in legal fees to the plaintiffs, ESA and EMA.<ref name="GP Judge Dumfounded">{{cite web |url=http://gamepolitics.com/2007/04/16/federal-judge-dumbfounded-by-jack-thompsons-failed-louisiana-game-law/ |title=Judge Trashes Louisiana Govt. Over Failed Jack Thompson Law, Orders State to Pay Legal Fees |last=McCauley |first=Dennis |authorlink=Dennis McCauley |coauthors= |date=2007-04-16 |year= |month= |format= |work= |publisher=[[GamePolitics.com]] |pages= |language= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160628012606/http://gamepolitics.com/2007/04/16/federal-judge-dumbfounded-by-jack-thompsons-failed-louisiana-game-law/ |archivedate=June 28, 2016 |access-date=October 13, 2016 |dead-url=yes}}</ref>
Representative Roy Burrell stated that he may pursue such legislation again in the future.<ref name="KATC">{{cite web |url=http://www.katc.com/Global/story.asp?S=6374154 |title=State has to pay legal fees over defunct video law |accessdate=2007-04-16 |last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |date= |year= |month= |format= |work= |publisher=[[KATC (TV)|KATC]] |pages= |language= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928065417/http://www.katc.com/Global/story.asp?S=6374154|archivedate=2007-09-28|dead-url=yes |quote= }}</ref>
==References== <references />
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070912125810/http://www.legis.state.la.us/billdata/byinst.asp?sessionid=06rs&billtype=SB&billno=340 HB1381 - 2006 Regular Session (Act 441)] at the Louisiana's Assembly website * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070912125810/http://www.legis.state.la.us/billdata/byinst.asp?sessionid=06rs&billtype=SB&billno=340 SB340 - 2006 Regular Session (Act 529)] at the Louisiana's Assembly website * [http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20091228173003/http://gamepolitics.livejournal.com/tag/hb1381 coverage of HB1381] on [[GamePolitics.com]]
{{Video game controversy}}

revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[image:Environment-Triptych-2008-terracotta-portraits-sculptor-Jon-Edgar.jpg|thumb|right|''Environment Triptych'']] The '''''Environment Triptych''''', by sculptor [[Jon Edgar]], is a group of three portrait heads of environmental thinkers of the day. First assembled in 2008,<ref>http://jonedgar.files.wordpress.com/2011/05/2008-environment-triptych-mabey-midgley-lovelock.jpg</ref> it is composed of the terracotta heads of [[James Lovelock]], proposer of the [[Gaia hypothesis]], moral philosopher [[Mary Midgley]], and writer [[Richard Mabey]]. Edgar worked with three in either [[Cornwall]], [[Newcastle upon Tyne]] or [[Norfolk]] during visits in 2006 and 2007.
The heads have a relevance as individual portraits, but the interplay of the three heads plinthed together seemed to add something; perhaps emphasising the sitters’ diverse efforts in influencing human behaviour and our interaction with the planet and its other organisms.<ref>http://jonedgar.wordpress.com/2011/05/17/the-environment-series-heads/</ref> The ''Triptych'' has led to the ''[[Environment Series]]'' of heads of environmentally aware sitters,<ref>article on the Human Clay exhibition, Surrey Advertiser. 2 Dec 2011 p.11</ref><ref>http://www.surrey.ac.uk/arts/visualarts/exhibitions%20and%20events/the_human_clay_jon_edgar.htm</ref><ref>http://www.surrey.ac.uk/arts/visualarts/exhibitions%20and%20events/The%20Human%20Clay%20Exhibition.pdf</ref> including [[Chris Rapley]], [[Gordon Murray]], [[Tim Smit]], and [[Guy Watson]].
==References== {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:2008 sculptures]] [[Category:English sculpture]] [[Category:Environmental art]] [[Category:Portraits of historical figures]] [[Category:Terracotta sculptures]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Catalog-25-Anniversary-of-Victory-70-bw.jpg | backcolor=#FBF5DF | painting_alignment=right | image_size=200px | title= ''Exhibition of Leningrad artists of 1970. Catalog'' | artist= | year=1970 | height_metric= | width_metric= | height_imperial= | width_imperial= | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city= [[Saint Petersburg|''Leningrad'']] | museum=[[Saint Petersburg Union of Artists|''Leningrad Union of Soviet Artists Exhibition Halls'']] }} '''Exhibition of Leningrad artists of 1970 dedicated to 25th Anniversary of Victory over Nazi Germany''' ({{lang-ru|"Выставка произведений ленинградских художников 1970 года, посвящённая 25-летию Победы над фашистской Германией"}}) was opened in Exhibition Halls of the [[Saint Petersburg Union of Artists|''Leningrad Union of Soviet Artists'']] and become one of notable Art Exhibition of 1970 in the USSR.
== History and organization == For the organization and preparation of Exhibition was formed Exhibition Committee in consist of authoritative art-experts. Exhibition Catalog was published.<ref>''Выставка произведений ленинградских художников, посвященная 25-летию Победы над фашистской Германией. Каталог.'' Л., Художник РСФСР, 1972.</ref> At whole Exhibition attended over 220 artists of the Leningrad.
== Contributing artists == In the largest Department of Painting were exhibited art works of 81 authors. There were Vladimir Andreev, [[Sergei Babkov (painter)|Sergei Babkov]], [[Nikolai Baskakov (painter)|Nikolai Baskakov]], [[Yuri Belov]], [[Dmitry Belyaev (artist)|Dmitry Belyaev]], Alexander Blinkov, [[Veniamin Borisov]], [[Dmitry Buchkin]], [[Rostislav Vovkushevsky]], [[Nikolai Galakhov]], Evgeny Galunov, [[Vasily Golubev (painter)|Vasily Golubev]], Alexander Gulayev, Nina Ivanova, [[Mikhail Kozell]], [[Elena Kostenko]], Anna Kostina, [[Yaroslav Krestovsky]], [[Boris Lavrenko]], [[Ivan Lavsky]], Efim Latsky, Vladimir Malagis, [[Mikhail Natarevich]], [[Yuri Neprintsev]], [[Dmitry Oboznenko]], [[Ivan Savenko]], [[Vladimir Seleznev]], [[Alexander Mikhailovich Semionov|Alexander Semionov]], [[Arseny Semionov]], [[Joseph Serebriany]], [[Nikolai Timkov]], [[Yuri Tulin]], and others painters of the [[Leningrad School of Painting|Leningrad School]].<ref>''Выставка произведений ленинградских художников, посвященная 25-летию Победы над фашистской Германией. Каталог.'' Л., Художник РСФСР, 1972.</ref>
In the Department of Sculptures were exhibited art works of 23 sculptors. Department of graphics presented a creation of 83 artists.
== Contributed artworks == For exposure have been selected works of painting, sculpture and graphics, applied art created by artists from Leningrad during the Great Patriotic War and the siege of Leningrad, as well as in during of postwar decades. Some of them were subsequently found in the collections of Soviet Art museums, as well as domestic and foreign galleries and collectors.
== Acknowledgment == Exhibition of Leningrad artists of 1970 was widely covered in press and in literature on Soviet fine art.<ref>''Художники народов СССР. Биобиблиографический словарь. Т.1-4.''. М., Искусство, 1970-1995.</ref><ref>''Хроника узловых событий художественной жизни России 1960-1980-х годов'' // Time for Change. The Art of 1960-1985 in the Soviet Union. Saint Petersburg, State Russian Museum, 2006.</ref><ref>''Sergei V. Ivanov. Unknown Socialist Realism. The Leningrad School.'' Saint Petersburg, NP-Print Edition, 2007. P.396, 417.</ref>
== See also == * [[Fine Art of Leningrad]] * [[Leningrad School of Painting]] * [[1970 in fine arts of the Soviet Union]] * [[Saint Petersburg Union of Artists]] * [[Socialist realism]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
== Sources ==
* ''Выставка произведений ленинградских художников, посвященная 25-летию Победы над фашистской Германией. Каталог.'' Л., Художник РСФСР, 1972. * ''Справочник членов Ленинградской организации Союза художников РСФСР''. Л., Художник РСФСР, 1980. * ''Художники народов СССР. Биобиблиографический словарь. Т.1-4''. М., Искусство, 1970-1995. * ''Справочник членов Союза художников СССР. Т.1-2''. М., Советский художник, 1979. * ''Хроника узловых событий художественной жизни России 1960-1980-х годов'' // Time for Change. The Art of 1960-1985 in the Soviet Union. Saint Petersburg, State Russian Museum, 2006. * ''Sergei V. Ivanov. Unknown Socialist Realism. The Leningrad School.'' Saint Petersburg, NP-Print Edition, 2007. P.395, 417, 442. {{ISBN|5-901724-21-6}}, {{ISBN|978-5-901724-21-7}} * ''Юбилейный Справочник выпускников Санкт-Петербургского академического института живописи, скульптуры и архитектуры имени И. Е. Репина Российской Академии художеств. 1915—2005.'' Санкт Петербург, «Первоцвет», 2007.

revision.text:
The '''Heller Theatre''' in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]] is the largest community theatre in Oklahoma. It was founded in October 1981 by Ken Spence with the partnership of [[Theatre Tulsa]] and has since produced more than one hundred shows including two dozen world premiers. The theater is currently directed by Julie Tattershall operated by the Tulsa Parks and Recreation Department.
The theater was named the Oklahoma Community Theatre Association (OCTA) Theater of the Year in 2005. The Great Plains debut of [[Yasmina Reza]]'s “The Unexpected Man," translated by [[Christopher Hampton]], received high honors from (OCTA) in 2007. Two of the Heller's most recent shows were named "Top Ten" performances of the Year by the ''[[Tulsa World]]''.<ref> Heller Theatre Brings Three Troupes, Offerings to SummerStage. ''Tulsa World'' June 23, 2006</ref><ref>''Daily Oklahoman'', April 1, 2005</ref>
The theater is also home to Oklahoma's oldest comedy troupe, The Laughing Matter Improv, founded in 1993, and Round the Bend Players, one of the nation's leading senior theaters. Its current directors are Rita Boyle and Sherry Zyskowski. Round the Bend's production of Jacob Appel's "The Three Belles of Eden" was a critic's pick in the ''Tulsa World''.<ref>Shade, Karen. Round the Bend Players offer funny, sometimes dark story. ''Tulsa World'' August 24, 2006</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.hellertheatre.com/ Official website]
[[Category:Performing groups established in 1981]] [[Category:Community theatre]] [[Category:Culture of Tulsa, Oklahoma]] [[Category:Theatre companies in Oklahoma]] [[Category:Economy of Tulsa, Oklahoma]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Tulsa, Oklahoma]] [[Category:Theatres in Oklahoma]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox magazine | title = Janus | logo = | logo_size = | image_file = Janus (science fiction magazine) 1977 issue 9.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = 1977 cover | editor = Janice Bogstad
Jeanne Gomoll | editor_title = | previous_editor = | staff_writer = | photographer = | category = [[feminism|Feminist]] [[science fiction]] | frequency = | circulation = | publisher = | founder = | founded = | firstdate = {{Start date|1975|12}} | finaldate = Winter 1980 | finalnumber = 18 | company = | country = USA | based = [[Madison, Wisconsin]] | language = | website = | issn = 0197-775X | oclc = }} '''''Janus''''' was a [[feminism|feminist]] [[science fiction]] [[science fiction fanzine|fanzine]] edited by [[Janice Bogstad]] and [[Jeanne Gomoll]] in [[Madison, Wisconsin]], and closely associated with that city's [[science fiction convention]], [[WisCon]] (Several early WisCon [[program book]]s doubled as special issues of ''Janus''.)"What is WisCon?:History of Wiscon" It was repeatedly nominated for the [[Hugo Award for Best Fanzine]] (1978, 1979 and 1980);[http://www.locusmag.com/SFAwards/Db/HugoNomList.html Hugo Nominee List] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110920202744/http://www.locusmag.com/SFAwards/Db/HugoNomList.html |date=2011-09-20 }} this led to accusations that if ''Janus'' had not been feminist, it wouldn't have been nominated.Merrick, Helen. "From female man to feminist fan: uncovering herstory in the annals of SF fandom," in ''Women of Other Worlds: Excursions Through Science Fiction and Feminism'' Helen Merrick and Tess Williams, eds. Univ. of Western Australia Press, 1999, p. 129-ff.Gomoll, Jeanne. "An Open Letter to Joanna Russ," ''Six Shooter'' (Jeanne Gomoll, Linda Pickersgill and Pam Wells, eds. [1987]; reprinted in ''Fanthology '87'' Eighteen issues were published under this name from 1975–1980; it was succeeded by ''[[Aurora SF]]'' (''Aurora Speculative Feminism'').[http://feministsf.org/crit/zines.html Feminist Science Fiction, Fantasy, and Utopia:Journals, Newsletters, & 'Zines][http://library.temple.edu/collections/special_collections/fanzine.jsp;jsessionid=DD33A759A422E62B4B582F59E618187B?bhcp=1&bhhash=1#j Temple University Libraries Fanzine Collection: J] == Contributors == During its run, ''Janus'' included articles, reviews, artwork and/or [[letter of comment|letters of comment]] from a variety of notables, including: [[Amanda Bankier]], [[Marion Zimmer Bradley]], [[Walter Breen]], [[Linda Bushyager]], [[Avedon Carol]], [[Suzy McKee Charnas]], [[C. J. Cherryh]], [[Buck Coulson]], [[Samuel R. Delany]], [[Gene DeWeese]], [[Harlan Ellison]], [[Alexis Gilliland]], [[Mike Glicksohn]], [[Joan Hanke-Woods]], [[Teddy Harvia]] (both as Harvia and under his real name of David Thayer), [[Ursula K. Le Guin]], [[Elizabeth Lynn]], [[Loren MacGregor]], [[Katherine Maclean]], [[Vonda McIntyre]], [[Alexei Panshin]], [[Andrew I. Porter|Andy Porter]], [[William Rotsler]], [[Joanna Russ]], [[Jessica Amanda Salmonson]], [[Charles R. Saunders]], [[Stu Shiffman]], [[Gene Simmons]], [[Wilson Tucker|Wilson "Bob" Tucker]], [[Joan Vinge]], [[Harry Warner, Jr.]], [[F. Paul Wilson]], [[Donald A. Wollheim]], and [[Susan Wood (science fiction)|Susan Wood]]. ==See also== * [[Feminist science fiction]] * [[Wiscon]] * ''[[The Witch and the Chameleon]]'' * [[Women in speculative fiction]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *''[http://www.sf-encyclopedia.com/entry/janus/aurora Janus/Aurora]'' at ''The Encyclopedia of Science Fiction'' *[http://sf3.org/history/janus-aurora-covers/ ''Janus'' online] {{DEFAULTSORT:Janus (science fiction magazine)}} [[Category:Defunct women's magazines of the United States]] [[Category:Defunct science fiction magazines of the United States]] [[Category:Feminist criticism]] [[Category:Feminist literature]] [[Category:Feminist magazines]] [[Category:Feminist science fiction]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1975]] [[Category:Magazines disestablished in 1980]] [[Category:Magazines published in Wisconsin]] [[Category:Science fiction fanzines]] [[Category:Media in Madison, Wisconsin]] {{US-lit-mag-stub}} {{science-fiction-stub}}

{{about|the Korean Film Archive|other uses|Kofa (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox Korean name |img=Kofa_logo.jpg |caption=Korean Film Archive official logotype |imgwidth=100 |hangul=한국영상자료원 |hanja=韓國映像資料院 |rr=Han'guk yeongsang jaryowon |mr=Han'kuk yǒngsang charyowǒn }} The '''Korean Film Archive''' or called '''Korean Federation of Film Archives''' and '''KOFA''' is the sole film archive in [[South Korea]] with nationwide coverage. It was founded in [[Seoul]] in 1974 as a non-profit organization. In 1976 KOFA joined the [[International Federation of Film Archives]] (FIAF) as an observer, and gained its full membership of FIAF in 1985.<ref name="Doosan">{{cite web|url=http://www.encyber.com/search_w/ctdetail.php?&masterno=703468&contentno=703468 |title=한국영상자료원 Korean Federation of Film Archives 韓國映像資料院|publisher=[[Doosan Encyclopedia]] |language=Korean}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.koreafilm.org/kofa/history.asp |title=Korean Film Archive |publisher=Koreafilm.org |date= |accessdate=2010-02-06}}</ref>
KOFA's main duties are to collect, preserve and categorize films and film-related materials, as well as to foster accessibility to its collections. Most of remaining originals and copies of Korean films are preserved in KOFA. Its main center is in [[Sangam-dong]], Seoul, with two local branch centers in [[Busan]] and [[Bucheon]], and a secondary preservation center in [[Seongnam]]. Its main center has several public facilities, including Cinematheque KOFA,<ref>http://www.koreafilm.org/theatre/schedule.asp</ref> Korean Film Museum,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.koreafilm.org/museum/introduction.asp |title=Korean Film Archive |publisher=Koreafilm.org |date= |accessdate=2010-02-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100115025259/http://www.koreafilm.org/museum/introduction.asp |archivedate=2010-01-15 |df= }}</ref> and a reference library.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.koreafilm.org/library/library.asp |title=Korean Film Archive |publisher=Koreafilm.org |date= |accessdate=2010-02-06}}</ref> Recently KOFA has concentrated on digitization of Korean films, and has published several features of the Classic Korean Cinema DVD Collections.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.koreafilm.org/publica/dvds.asp |title=Korean Film Archive |publisher=Koreafilm.org |date= |accessdate=2010-02-06}}</ref> It also operates the most reliable online database of Korean films,<ref name="한국영화 데이터베이스 KMDB">{{cite web|url=http://www.kmdb.or.kr/eng/index.asp |title=한국영화 데이터베이스 KMDB |publisher=Kmdb.or.kr |date= |accessdate=2010-02-06}}</ref> as well as an online film streaming service.<ref name="한국영화 데이터베이스 KMDB"/>
== History == It was established as a Korean film storage center in 1974 in Namsan-dong, Jung-gu, Seoul, and moved to Seocho-dong in 1990. Since 1991, it has been renamed as Korea Media Center by foundations. It was reorganized into a special corporation based on the Motion Picture Promotion Act in 2002. It built its own building in Sangam-dong, Mapo-gu in May 2007 and formally reopened in the following year. It is composed of auxiliary and restored facilities equipped with an anti-air and photo-related facility for preserving film and other materials, Cinema Tech that provides movie screening and current affairs services, and a cinema that illuminates Korean film industry through the exhibition of film related materials. It is a member of the International Federation of Film Executions (FIAF) regular members, who hosted the Federation General Meeting in Seoul in 2002. It is a public organization for cultural services under the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism in Korea government.
== Functions == KOFA serves three main duties and various kinds of referential access services: * Film Collection and Categorization * Film Preservation, Restoration and Digitization * Film Screening and Referential Services * Publication of Academic and Referential Resources * Operation of Online Databases on Korean Cinema * [http://www.koreafilm.org/english/db_sch02.asp KOFA Film Collection Search] * [[Korean Movie Database]] online
== See also == * [[International Federation of Film Archives]] * [[Cinematheque]] * [[Cinema of Korea]]
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
== External links == * [http://www.koreafilm.org/ Korean Film Archive website] * [http://www.kmdb.or.kr/eng/vod/vod_enMain.asp Korean Film Video On Demand] * [http://www.theauteurs.com/films/2039 ''Housemaid''(1960) restored by the Korean Film Archive with the support of the [[World Cinema Foundation]]]

revision.comment: /* List */ link to the main pages of different countries
revision.text:
{{Pp-move-indef}} {{Main article|Film censorship}} This is a '''list of banned films'''.
For nearly the entire [[history of film]] production, certain films have been [[Ban (law)|banned]] by film censorship or review organizations for political or [[morality|moral]] reasons or for controversial content, such as racism. Censorship standards vary widely by country, and can vary within an individual country over time due to political or moral change.
Many countries have government-appointed or private commissions to censor and rate productions for film and television exhibition. While it is common for films to be edited to fall into certain rating classifications, this list includes only films that have been explicitly prohibited from public screening.
{{horizontal TOC|nonum=yes}}
==List==
:''Note that for some countries films are banned on a wide scale and are not listed in this table.'' :''Separate lists for some countries are listed below this table'' <!--
PLEASE UPDATE THE ARTICLE FOR INDIVIDUAL COUNTRIES WHERE THEY EXIST
--> {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:100%;" |- ! style="width:8%;"|Date ! style="width:22%;"|Title ! style="width:10%;"|Country/Organization !! class="unsortable" style="width:60%;"|Notes |- |align=center | 1996–2001 | '''All''' |align=center | [[Afghanistan]] | During the [[Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan|five-year reign]] of the [[Taliban]] government in Afghanistan, Western technology and art was prohibited and this included ''all'' films.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lang.sbsun.com/socal/terrorist/1101/20/terror09.asp|title=After five-year Taliban ban, television and movies return to Afghanistan|publisher=Lang.sbsun.com|accessdate=2015-02-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rawa.org/rules.htm|title=some of the restrictions imposed by Taliban in Afghanistan|publisher=Rawa.org|accessdate=2015-02-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NubtDf2T3cAC&pg=PA84|title=Inside Afghanistan|accessdate=2015-02-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bunHURgi7FcC&pg=PA7|title=Encyclopedia of Censorship|accessdate=2015-02-16}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1980–1990 | ''Pas vdekjes'' (''After Death'') |align=center | [[Albania]] | Banned for ten years.<ref name="kviff">{{cite web|url=http://www.kviff.com/en/programme/film/082582-magic-eye/|title=KVIFF | Magic Eye|publisher=kviff.com|accessdate=2016-07-12}}</ref> |- |align=center| 2017 | ''[[Wonder Woman (2017 film)|Wonder Woman]]'' |align=center | [[Lebanon]], [[Qatar]], and [[Tunisia]] | Pulled from distribution in [[Lebanon]] before premiere on account of that film's lead star [[Gal Gadot]]'s service in the [[Israeli Army]], leading to a campaign against her and in accordance with a decades-old law that boycotts Israeli products and bars Lebanese citizens from traveling to Israel or having contacts with Israelis. Lebanon is at war with Israel. However, that film will be viewed online and available on DVD instead.<ref name="Page Six">{{cite news|title=Lebanon officially bans 'Wonder Woman'|url=http://pagesix.com/2017/06/01/lebanon-officially-bans-wonder-woman/|accessdate=3 June 2017|work=Page Six|agency=Associated Press|date=1 June 2017}}</ref> Due to the [[Arab League boycott of Israel]], it is also banned in [[Qatar]] and [[Tunisia]].<ref>http://www.jpost.com/Not-Just-News/Tunisian-court-bans-showing-of-Wonder-Woman-over-Gal-Gadots-IDF-service-496590</ref><ref>http://www.jpost.com/Arab-Israeli-Conflict/Qatar-bans-Wonder-Woman-over-lead-Israeli-actress-Gal-Gadot-498595</ref> |- |align=center | 1941 | ''[[I'll Never Heil Again]]'' | rowspan="13" align="center" | [[Argentina]] | Banned during the "[[Infamous Decade]]" dictatorship (1930-1943) for lampooning [[Nazi Germany]]; Argentina had declared itself [[Neutral powers during World War II|neutral during World War Two]].<ref name="latimes1">{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/opinion/opinion-la/la-ol-north-korea-the-interview-banned-movies-20141222-story.html |title=Beyond 'The Interview': A short list of films banned for political reasons |publisher=LA Times |date=2014-12-23 |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1963 | ''[[The Silence (1963 film)|The Silence]]'' | Banned because of "obscenity".<ref name="google1969">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gDqsCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA807 |title=Censorship: A World Encyclopedia |page=807 |date=2015-05-22 |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1972 | ''[[Last Tango in Paris]]'' | Banned during the self-styled "[[Argentine Revolution]]" dictatorship (1966-1973), for being "pornographic".<ref name="google1969"/> |- |align=center | 1974 | ''[[La Patagonia rebelde]]'' (''Rebel Patagonia'') | Banned under [[Isabel Perón]]'s government (1974-1975) and [[Jorge Rafael Videla]]'s regime during [[National Reorganization Process|Argentina's last-civil military dictatorship]] (1976-1983). The historical film is about the suppression of a peasants' revolt, known as "[[Patagonia Trágica|Tragic Patagonia]]".<ref name="google1969" /> |- |align=center | 1976 | ''[[The Great Dictator]]'' (1940) | Banned under Videla's regime during Argentina's last-civil military dictatorship (1976-1983), for mocking dictatorships.<ref name="google1969"/> |- |align=center | 1978 | ''[[Long Vacations of 36|Las largas vacaciones del '36]]'' | Banned under Videla's regime during Argentina's last-civil military dictatorship (1976-1983), for its sarcastic view of [[Francoist Spain]].<ref name="google1969"/> |- |align=center | 1978 | ''[[Looking for Mr. Goodbar]]'' | Banned under Videla's regime during Argentina's last-civil military dictatorship (1976-1983), for being "pornographic".<ref name="google1969" /> |- |align=center | 1978 | ''[[Pretty Baby (1978 film)|Pretty Baby]]'' | Banned under Videla's regime during Argentina's last-civil military dictatorship (1976-1983), for being "pornographic".<ref name="google1969" /> |- |align=center | 1979 | ''[[Coming Home (1978 film)|Coming Home]]'' | Banned under Videla's regime during Argentina's last-civil military dictatorship (1976-1983), for its anti-war message.<ref name="google1969"/> |- |align=center | 1979 | ''[[The House on Garibaldi Street]]'' | Banned under Videla's regime during Argentina's last-civil military dictatorship (1976-1983), because it depicts the hunt for Nazi criminal [[Adolf Eichmann]].<ref name="google1969"/> |- |align=center | 1985 | ''[[Hail Mary (film)|Je vous salue, Marie]]'' (''Hail Mary'') | Banned due to blasphemous and sexual content.<ref>{{cite book | title = The Films Of Jean-Luc Godard (Cambridge Film Classics) | author = Sterritt, David | publisher = Cambridge University Press | isbn = 0-521-58971-1 | year = 2003 | page = 166}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1987 | ''[[The Last Temptation of Christ (film)|The Last Temptation of Christ]]'' | Banned for being considered as "blasphemy".<ref name="criterion1">{{cite web|url=https://www.criterion.com/lists/170366-banned-criterion-s-forbidden-films |title=Banned! Criterion's Forbidden Films |website=Criterion.com |date= |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=Citation is a list developed by a user from the Criterion site.|date=June 2017}}<ref>[http://malditosnerds.com/notas/id/12225/10-pelculas-prohibidas-en-Argentina#9 Ten films banned in Argentina] Malditos Nerds {{es}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1989 | ''[[Kindergarten (1989 film)|Kindergarten]]'' | Banned for its controversial themes, scenes of nudity and [[Unsimulated sex|unsimulated]] [[Fellatio|oral sex]]. A [[court order]] required all copies of the film to be seized and a ban on its exhibition.<ref>[https://books.google.com.ar/books?id=gDqsCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA1881&lpg=PA1881&dq=kindergarten+1989+censored+film&source=bl&ots=_6C_4uJm1M&sig=QnVc7j3ZWWempqzrfvgJQ3_FxSg&hl=es&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiY7_2Qqs3ZAhXmw1kKHWRCAVkQ6AEIcDAM#v=onepage&q=kindergarten%201989%20censored%20film&f=false Censorship: A World Encyclopedia (edited by Derek Jones)] [[Google Books]]</ref> The film was finally shown in a restored copy in 2010, as part of the [[Mar del Plata International Film Festival]].<ref>[http://www.clarin.com/espectaculos/cine/Kindergarten_0_374362762.html Forbidden film "Kindergarten" is released after 21 years] 11-18-2010, ''[[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)|Clarín]]'' {{es}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1972 | ''[[Pink Flamingos]]'' | rowspan="5" align="center" |{{main|List of films banned in Australia}} | Banned on its initial release until the 1980s due to offensive content.<ref name="anothermag1">{{cite web|url=http://www.anothermag.com/design-living/7505/the-best-banned-films |title=The Best Banned Films | AnOther |website=Anothermag.com |date=2015-06-12 |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1975–1992 | ''[[Salò, or the 120 Days of Sodom]]'' | Banned on its initial release,<ref name="google1969"/> but lifted after seventeen years.<ref name="berlinfilmjournal1">{{cite web|last=Beaney |first=Harriet |url=http://berlinfilmjournal.com/2014/09/controversial-cinema-top-10-banned-films/ |title=Controversial Cinema: Top 10 Banned Films |publisher=Berlin Film Journal |date= |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1976–2000 | ''[[In the Realm of the Senses]]'' | Banned because of obscenity, though a censored version was made available in 1977. Only in 2000, did it finally become available in its complete cut.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.refused-classification.com/censorship/films/in-the-realm-of-the-senses-1976.html|title=In the Realm of the Senses (1976) - Censor - Refused-Classification.com|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QPQAgMM79bcC&pg=PT42|title=Offensive to a Reasonable Adult|publisher=}}</ref> |- |align=center | 2011 | ''[[The Human Centipede 2 (Full Sequence)]]'' | Temporarily banned for cruel, disturbing, and sexually explicit content. A censored DVD version was later released on February 23, 2012.<ref>{{cite press release |title=The Human Centipede II (full sequence) classified RC upon review |publisher=Classification Review Board |date=28 November 2011 |url=http://www.classification.gov.au/www/cob/rwpattach.nsf/VAP/%289A5D88DBA63D32A661E6369859739356%29~CRB+-+Media+Release+-+HC+II+-+RC+-+28+Nov+2011.pdf/$file/CRB+-+Media+Release+-+HC+II+-+RC+-+28+Nov+2011.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2011-12-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111215232003/http://www.classification.gov.au/www/cob/rwpattach.nsf/VAP/(9A5D88DBA63D32A661E6369859739356)~CRB+-+Media+Release+-+HC+II+-+RC+-+28+Nov+2011.pdf/$file/CRB+-+Media+Release+-+HC+II+-+RC+-+28+Nov+2011.pdf |archivedate=15 December 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.crikey.com.au/cinetology/2011/12/07/the-human-centipede-ii-to-be-resubmitted-to-the-classification-review-board/|title=Human Centipede 2 to be resubmitted for classification|publisher=[[Crikey]]|accessdate=2011-12-09}}</ref><ref name="Canberra">{{cite web|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/news/local/news/general/cut-horror-film-to-crawl-back-on-screens/2392167.aspx|title=Cut horror film to crawl back on screens|work=[[The Canberra Times]]|accessdate=2011-12-14}}</ref><ref name="Canberra"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/MonsterPics/status/146789964049428480|title=Twitter / @MonsterPics: Prepare to lose your shit. ...|publisher=Twitter|accessdate=2011-12-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jbhifionline.com.au/dvd/dvd-genres/horror-thriller/human-centipede-2-the-blu-ray/659415|title=Human Centipede 2, The (Blu-ray)|publisher=[[JB Hi-Fi]]|accessdate=2011-12-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jbhifionline.com.au/dvd/dvd-genres/horror-thriller/human-centipede-2-the/659416 |title=Human Centipede 2, The |publisher=JB Hi-Fi |accessdate=2011-12-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120206151805/http://www.jbhifionline.com.au/dvd/dvd-genres/horror-thriller/human-centipede-2-the/659416 |archivedate=2012-02-06 |df= }}</ref> |- |align=center | 2003 | ''[[Ken Park]]'' | Banned and refused classification in 2003 for graphic depictions of teenage sex, incest, and auto-erotic asphyxiation.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/07/03/1057179099732.html | location=Sydney | first=Kirsy | last=Needham | title=Police quiz critic after raid | date=2003-07-04}}</ref> |- |align=center | 2011 | ''[[:az:Girov (film, 2005)|Hostage]]'' <small>(Azerbaijani)</small> |align=center | [[Azerbaijan]] | Banned because the plot presents [[Armenians]] in a positive light.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://panarmenian.net/eng/culture/news/63440/Baku_gets_to_absurdity_a_positive_film_about_Armenians_banned_in_Azerbaijan |title=Baku gets to absurdity: a positive film about Armenians banned in Azerbaijan |website=Panarmenian.Net |date=2011-03-07 |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref> |- |align=center | 2007 | ''[[The Kingdom (film)|The Kingdom]]'' | rowspan="2" align="center" | [[Bahrain]] | Banned because of an inaccurate depiction of a 1996 bombing in [[Saudi Arabia]].<ref name="alarabiya2007">{{cite web|url=https://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2007/10/12/40274.html |title=Movie 'The Kingdom' banned in two Gulf states |website=English.alrabiya.net |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref> |- |align=center | 2014 | ''[[Noah (2014 film)|Noah]]'' | Banned due to depiction of prophets.<ref name="cbn.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.cbn.com/cbnnews/us/2014/March/Noah-Banned-in-Most-of-the-Muslim-World/|title='Noah' Banned in Most of the Muslim World|publisher=Cbn.com|accessdate=2015-02-16}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1940–1945 | ''[[Carnival in Flanders (film)|La Kermesse Heroïque]]'' (''Carnival in Flanders'') (1935) | rowspan="2" align=center | [[Belgium]] | Banned in Nazi-occupied Belgium by [[Joseph Goebbels]] because of its [[pacifist]] themes. The director, [[Jacques Feyder]], was later hunted down for arrest but managed to hide in Switzerland.<ref name="google">{{cite book|title=Selling Hollywood to the World: US and European Struggles for Mastery of the Global Film Industry, 1920-1950|author=Trumpbour, J.|date=2007|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521042666|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H0aGyzjFBAcC&pg=PA212|page=212|accessdate=2016-07-12}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1976–1994 | ''[[In the Realm of the Senses]]'' | Banned on its initial release because of its graphic sex scenes, being the last film subject to censorship in the country.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cinemazuid.be/nl/film/het-rijk-der-zinnen-l%E2%80%99empire-des-sensai-no-corrida |title=Cinemazuid |website=Cinemazuid.be |date=2013-04-25 |accessdate=2016-01-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160125215805/http://www.cinemazuid.be/nl/film/het-rijk-der-zinnen-l%E2%80%99empire-des-sensai-no-corrida |archivedate=2016-01-25 |df= }}</ref> It was the only European country at that time where the film was banned.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cobra.canvas.be/cm/cobra/videozone/dagopdag2014/november%2B2014/1.2144641|title=Video: Op 17 november 1977 zond de VRT dit uit|work=Cobra.be |language=nl}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dbnl.org/tekst/_ons003198601_01/_ons003198601_01_0134.php |title=Ons Erfdeel. Jaargang 29 · dbnl |website=Dbnl.org |date= |accessdate=2016-01-11}}</ref> Since 1994 <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nova-cinema.org/prog/2013/139b-and-cut/belgique-ceci-n-est-pas-de-la/?lang=nl|title=Nova Cinema|publisher=}}</ref> the ban is no longer in effect.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.filmmagie.be/nieuws/adieu-nagisa-oshima-1932-2013|title=Adieu Nagisa Oshima (1932-2013) - Filmmagie|publisher=}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1974 | ''[[The Texas Chain Saw Massacre]]'' | rowspan="2" align="center" | [[Brazil]] | Banned because of its content.<ref name="shortlist.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.shortlist.com/entertainment/films/10-banned-films#art|title=10 Banned Films - ShortList Magazine|work=ShortList Magazine}}</ref> |- |align=center | 2011 | ''[[A Serbian Film]]'' | Banned due to it being an "apology for pedophilia".<ref>[http://tribunadonorte.com.br/news.php?not_id=190156] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140227221858/http://tribunadonorte.com.br/news.php?not_id=190156|date=February 27, 2014}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1967–1990 | ''[[The Tied Up Balloon|Privarzaniyat balon]]'' (''The Tied Up Balloon'') | align=center | [[Bulgaria]] | Banned during the Communist era for criticizing the communist leaders during World War Two.<ref name="BNT">[http://bnt.bg/bg/movies/details/696/privyrzanijat_balon ''The Tied Up Balloon'' at the Bulgarian National Television] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130115201746/http://bnt.bg/bg/movies/details/696/privyrzanijat_balon |date=2013-01-15 }}</ref><ref>[http://bnf.bg/bg/odeon/movies/1004/ ''The Tied Up Balloon'' at Finally in Jan-1973 the butchered film premiered in Finland.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.elonet.fi/fi/elokuva/100787|title=Dirty Harry|work=Elonet|access-date=2018-03-15|language=fi}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1986 |''[[Born American]]'' |Banned on Jan-1986 for its violence and for political reasons.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.elonet.fi/fi/elokuva/113965|title=Born American|work=Elonet|access-date=2018-03-15|language=fi}}</ref> The political reasons were that the movie was "''potentially harmful to international relations''". A court appeal to Finnish Supreme administrative Court decided against the banning (after some cuts would be made) and authorities were forced to dismantle the ban (with more cuts) and the movie premiered in late Dec-1986 after a struggle of almost a year. 20 years after the movie was banned, it was revealed (by a politics researcher and academic [[Juhani Suomi]] in his book "''Kohti sinipunaa''") that the authorities were in fact "instructed" to ban the film and that the banning was dictated by the [[Soviet Union]]'s ambassador [[Vladimir Sobolev (diplomat)|Vladimir Sobolev]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/262737883|title=Kohti sinipunaa : Mauno Koiviston aika 1986-1987|last=1943-|first=Suomi, Juhani,|date=2008|publisher=Otava|isbn=9789511219699|location=Helsingissä|oclc=262737883}}</ref> Born American was the last movie in Finland to suffer banning for political reasons. |- |align=center | 1971–2000 |[[The Devils (film)|''The Devils'']] |Banned on its initial release in 1971 for violence and content which could potentially be hazardous to mental health. During [[World War II#Axis advance stalls (1942)|World War II]], it was once shown to German soldiers in 1942: In German-occupied Yugoslavia, local guerillas sneaked a copy from Greece into an army-cinema in an act of [[Psychological warfare|cultural sabotage]]. After half of the film had been shown, German officers stopped the screening and threatened to shoot the Yugoslavian projectionist. Apparently, the film was ordered by the [[Reich Chancellery]].<ref name="latimes1"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.spiegel.de/sptv/reportage/a-182140.html|title=Charlie Chaplin und der Führer: Heil Hynkel! |date=14 February 2002|work=Spiegel Online |language=de |accessdate=2015-02-16}}</ref> It was first shown in West Germany as late as 1958. |- |align=center | 1940–1945 | ''[[Carnival in Flanders (film)|La Kermesse Heroïque]]'' (''Carnival in Flanders'') (1935) | Banned in Nazi Germany and Belgium by [[Joseph Goebbels]] because of its pacifist themes. The director, [[Jacques Feyder]], was later hunted down for arrest, but managed to escape to Switzerland.<ref name="google">{{cite book|title=Selling Hollywood to the World: US and European Struggles for Mastery of the Global Film Industry, 1920-1950|author=Trumpbour, J.|date=2007|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521042666|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H0aGyzjFBAcC&pg=PA212|page=212|accessdate=2016-07-12}}</ref> |- |align=center | 1943−1949 | ''[[Titanic (1943 film)|Titanic]]'' (1943) | Banned in Nazi Germany by [[Joseph Goebbels]] because some of the scenes could demoralize the audience, despite being made by the Nazi propaganda department itself.
